Social Sectors Division, Southeast Asia Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Indonesia (the Government) has committed itself to poverty reduction 
by broadening and deepening its policy and intervention in social protection. The poor in the 
informal sector are more vulnerable to all variety of risks stemming from lack of protection against 
severe illness, disabilities, economic downturns, unemployment, and man-made and natural 
disasters. The Social Protection Strategy of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) emphasizes 
social protection as an important pillar of poverty reduction and complementing pro-poor growth. 
The Government has requested ADB’s assistance in preparing a sustainable social protection 
project. The Fact-Finding Mission1 for a technical assistance (TA),2 fielded in February 2003, 
agreed with the Government on the scope of work, implementation arrangements, financing 
arrangements,  and  timeframe  to  prepare  a  TA  for  the  proposed  project  that  meets  the 
requirements of ADB funding. The proposed TA is supported by ADB and the United Kingdom 
Department  for  International  Development  (DFID)  Partnership  for  Innovations  in  Poverty 
Reduction3 Program. Appendix 1 provides the logical framework for the TA. 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Although poverty has declined from its peak during the economic crisis of 1997-1998, the 
poverty rate slightly increased between 2001 and 2002.4 The incidence of poverty varies between 
provinces; in about 19 of the 32 provinces, more than 20% of the total population lived in poverty.5 
About one in four Indonesians is deprived of basic social services.6 For the poor and vulnerable 
populations a drop in income or increase in expenses can have disastrous effects on their 
standard of living. Sickness, death, or accidents may force the disposal of productive assets such 
as land or savings. Most people working in the informal economy7 have no social protection such 
as health and disability insurance. Major illness among the poor is one of the greatest and least 
predictable shocks to their economic opportunities.8 About 86% of the population is not covered 
by adequate health insurance. The largest share of the cost of illness is related to lost income and 
not health care expenditures.  
3.  Poverty  alleviation  interventions  are  traditionally  focused  on  expanding  economic 
opportunities based on the assumption that individuals and families have a potential for self-help. 
While this is true for some population groups, others, for example the elderly or handicapped, 
cannot avail of these opportunities. With a rising proportion of elderly and trends of increasing 
urbanization, the proportion of indigent elderly,9 without extended families in rural areas to return

run and will be a large claimant on social assistance for the poor.   
4.  Social protection in Indonesia is largely confined to social security schemes in the formal 
sector.  The social security system covers 25 million people, and is managed through state-run 
monopolies such as Perusahan Terbatas (PT) Askes and PT Jamostek.  ADB, in cooperation with 
other  agencies  such  as  the  International  Labour  Organization  (ILO),  is  supporting  the 
development of a national social security system.11 The new Social Security Law foresees the 
establishment of a national social security trust fund,12 to manage all social security programs (PT 
Askes, PT Taspen, PT ASBARI, and PT Jamsostek) by mid-2004. Since the extension of social 
security entitlements to the entire population is a long-term goal, social safety net schemes are 
essential for the 10 million households below the poverty line.  
5.  Traditionally, extended family members or the local community were obliged to support 
their poor relatives. The Social Safety Net (SSN) Program, an emergency intervention to 
mitigate the impact of the economic crisis, was set up at the onset of the crisis to support the 
Government in adequate service delivery for health care for the poor, education assistance, and 
scholarship programs. Drawing from lessons learned13 from ADB’s two social protection sector 
development programs,14 an SSN program should support service delivery by (i) addressing 
equity and quality considerations; (ii) developing local-level management and adopting flexible 
program  interventions  keeping  in  perspective  regional  variations;  and  (iii)  promoting  the 
Government’s role to shift toward standard-setting, monitoring, and capacity building. 
6.  Current formal social assistance programs remain limited in coverage and funding and 
do not distinguish between poor and vulnerable populations. For example, the Ministry of Social 
Affairs (MOSA) has established a social welfare insurance scheme that provides cash payments 
to families when the breadwinner is sick, is injured, or dies. It is unclear how many social 
protection schemes currently exist, what they cost, and if they complement or duplicate each 
other. Further, decentralization, which devolves central Government spending to regional levels, 
is likely to have implications on future social protection programs for the poor.15 An appropriate 
decision on fiscal devolution and transfer of subsidies to support such obligations would make 
such programs more manageable at regional level.  
7.  External support is largely confined to the development of the social security system. TA 
for social insurance is provided through the European Union (EU), ILO, World Bank, Canadian 
International Development Agency (CIDA), and German Technical Cooperation (GTZ), for the 
development of a social security law and a national social insurance system. The World Bank

8.  Indonesia  is  developing  an  integrated  social  protection  system  has  to  define  how 
affordable social protection will be composed. Because opportunities to expand coverage of 
formal social security and social insurance schemes to the poor are rather limited, it will be vital 
to  explore  options  (i)  identifying  linkages  between  formal  and  nonformal  social  protection 
schemes; (ii) strengthening informal schemes that build on traditional mutual support schemes 
and community participation for more effectively managing risks faced by the poor; and (iii) 
developing strategies for vulnerable groups, which may face a high risk of sliding into poverty 
because of illness or unemployment. Given the many situations and circumstances leading to 
poverty  in  different  parts  of  Indonesia,  varied  approaches  and  policies  may  be  required, 
considering regional needs and affordability to sustain social protection interventions.  Social 
protection policies and strategies for the poor will have to consider the  (i) vision for social 
protection in Indonesia, (ii) who should be helped and in what kind of circumstances, (iii) 
accurate means to identify the poor and vulnerable at the local level, (iv) affordability and 
possible funding sources for such schemes, and (v) polices to support individuals who are not 
capable of supporting themselves and live in especially difficult circumstances. Appendix 2 
provides the summary initial poverty and social analysis. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The purpose of the TA is to develop viable and sustainable social protection schemes 
that address the needs of the poor to reduce and cope with risks and vulnerability. The TA will 
assist the Government in preparing a draft policy framework for integrated social protection and 
a project proposal to identify social protection schemes especially for the informal sector. Based 
on the assessment, the TA will support development of a draft medium- and long-term policy. 
The policy draft will incorporate the shift from a centralized to a decentralized approach of 
service  delivery,  including  community-based  interventions  and  time-bound  strategies  for 
financing and operating social protection schemes.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will complement  ongoing TA and loans financed by ADB in essential social 
services17 as well as activities of other agencies. The TA will facilitate the dialogue between 
Government and civil society on social protection schemes and will be implemented in close 
cooperation  with  central  and  regional  governments,  the  private  sector,  nongovernment 
organizations, and research institutions with a focus on innovative service delivery and finance 
options for decentralized social protection schemes. The TA will be implemented in three phases 
during 9 months.

11.  Phase I includes the following outputs: (i) poverty, vulnerability, and summary labor market 
analyses; (ii) inventory and assessment of existing social protection policies and schemes; (iii) the 
best practices in other countries; (iv) definition of social protection in the Indonesian context; and 
(v) policy recommendations of the national workshop. Based on the outcomes of Phase I, Phase 
II will identify unmet needs and elaborate appropriate social protection schemes through national 
and district workshops. Outputs will include (i) identification of appropriate social protection 
interventions  distinguishing  poor  and  vulnerable  groups;  (ii)  methods  to  identify  eligible 
beneficiaries; (iii) options for central and regional governments18 to finance social protection, such 
as  cash  transfers,  matching  grants,  and  community-based  schemes;  (iv)  costing  and 
macroeconomic and financial frameworks to identify suitable social protection interventions using 
a  bottom-up  planning  process;(v)  legal  parameters  of  social  protection;  (vi)  framework  for 
cooperation on social protection among funding agencies; and (vii) recommendations of national 
and district planning workshops on suitable project components. Phase III will provide a detailed 
policy matrix and project description based on recommendations of Phase II, including rationale 
and expected outcomes, benefits, a fully developed logical framework, recommendations on 
institutional arrangements, and selection of the project’s executing and implementing agencies, 
estimates of inputs and costs, a monitoring and evaluation framework for the project with 
measurable indicators, and a project administration memorandum describing implementation 
procedures in detail. All project components will  be analyzed, as appropriate, for technical, 
financial, economic, social, and institutional viability and sustainability. 
B.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,000,000 equivalent, comprising $465,000 in 
foreign exchange and $535,000 equivalent in the local currency cost. ADB will finance $400,000 
equivalent on a grant basis from the ADB-funded TA program and $400,000 equivalent will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of the United Kingdom.  The Government will 
finance the balance of the local currency cost, equivalent to $200,000, through the provision of 
office and support facilities, experienced counterpart staff for administrative support, information 
and data collection, and logistical support (Appendix 3 provides details of the cost and financing 
plan). The Government has been advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project. 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Executing Agency (EA) for the TA will be the National Development Planning Agency 
(BAPPENAS)  acting  through  its  Directorate  for  Population,  Social  Welfare,  and  Women’s 
Empowerment, and the Directorate of Decentralization and Economic Affairs. BAPPENAS will be 
responsible for coordination across multiple line ministries for implementing the TA. To oversee 
the TA, a technical team will be established, which will include the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of 
Home  Affairs,  Ministry  of  Health,  MOSA,  the  National  Family  Planning  Coordinating  Board 
(BKKBN),  Ministry  of  Manpower  and  Transmigration,  Ministry  of  National  Education,  the 
Coordinating  Ministry  of  Social  Welfare,  directors  of  regional  government  and  counselor 
associations, and selected staff of regional governments. 
14.  The TA will provide technical support to the central and selected regional governments in 
setting a framework for integrated social protection, identifying and costing core social protection 
interventions  and  their  service  delivery  through  public-private  partnership  and  community

5 
involvement. A steering committee comprising main stakeholders such as BAPPENAS, Ministry of 
Health, BKKBN, MOSA, Ministry of Home Affairs, Ministry of Manpower and Labor, Ministry of 
Finance, the State Ministry of Women’s Empowerment, Association of Local Governments, civil 
society, and universities will be constituted by the end of the first month of the TA and will meet at 
least twice during the TA. The steering committee will be chaired by the Deputy Chairman of 
BAPPENAS for Human Resources and Cultural Affairs. An advisory committee consisting of 
representatives of regional governments will be constituted in time to take part in the TA inception 
workshop, and will provide advice to BAPPENAS on all aspects of TA design and implementation. 
The advisory committee  will meet on a monthly basis.  A project implementation unit will be 
established within BAPPENAS and will be responsible for all technical and administrative aspects 
of the TA. Suitably qualified counterpart staff will be seconded to work with the TA consultant 
team.  
15.  The TA will use participatory workshops to advocate social protection, undertake needs 
assessments, and identify local solutions for implementing social protection schemes, including 
for  a  loan  project.  The  TA  implementation  arrangements  will  provide  flexibility  to  allow 
adjustments to review outcomes of each phase. The consulting team, in cooperation with 
BAPPENAS, will organize workshops at the provincial and district levels to ensure participation 
of all stakeholders. The TA will be implemented during 9 months, to commence by September 
2003 and be completed by June 2004. ADB will engage a team of international (for 19 person-
months) and domestic (for 33 person-months) consultants with expertise in social protection, 
including social assistance and social insurance; institutional development, management, and 
legal analysis; social protection economy and financial analysis; gender and poverty; community 
development; and workshop facilitation. Appendix 4 provides the outline terms of reference for 
the  consultants.  Consultants  will  be  recruited  through  an  international  consulting  firm  in 
association with a local firm using quality- and cost-based selection in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
engagement of domestic consultants. Any procurement under the TA will be conducted in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
16.  The TA will be monitored and reviewed by ADB missions; regular communications with 
BAPPENAS; and inception, mid-term, and completion reports of the TA team. The TA team, in 
collaboration with the BAPPENAS counterpart team, will organize national- and regional-level 
workshops  to  ensure  participation  of  regional  stakeholders  in  defining  the  framework  for 
decentralized social protection and identifying project components. Tripartite reviews will be 
held to review progress made, and obtain input from central Government agencies, local 
governments, civil society, and representatives of communities. The consultants will produce (i) 
an inception report after 6 weeks, (ii) an interim report with results and recommendations from 
the first two rounds of workshops after 10 weeks, (iii) a midterm report after 4 months, (iv) a 
draft final report by the end of the eighth month, and (v) a final report by the end of the ninth 
month.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of the United Kingdom, and (ii) ADB providing the 
balance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000, on a grant basis, to the Government of the 
Republic  of  Indonesia for preparing the Sustainable Social Protection Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

SUMMARY INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Indonesia: 
 
Well-designed social protection policies and programs contribute to economic growth by facilitating investments in 
human capital and increasing labor productivity. Social protection helps societies make growth more equitable by 
balancing income fluctuation and broadening access to human capital development. Social protection aims to assist 
individuals to transform the negative cycle of poverty into a positive cycle of growth and human development. Social 
insurance programs cushion the risks associated with health, disability, work injury, unemployment, and old age. 
Social assistance and social welfare service programs provide subsistence to the most vulnerable groups with no 
other means of adequate support.   
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                Proposed Classification: Human Development 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
A vulnerability profile and labor market analysis will assist in prioritizing social protection needs, with a special focus 
on the nonformal sector. Priority vulnerable groups have to be identified and prioritized in the country’s vulnerability 
profile. Resources available for social protection programs have to be assessed through a social expenditure review 
during the technical assistance. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Stakeholder analysis?  Yes 
 
The technical assistance consultant team will consult with (i) central and regional governments; (ii) the private sector, 
including nongovernment organizations; (iii) research institutions and universities; and (iv) external agencies working 
in social protection. Consultative and planning workshops will be held to develop both a draft policy framework for 
social protection and the design of a loan project.  
 
 
Participation strategy? To be prepared 
 
 
D.  Gender and Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
The project will ensure that social protection schemes are developed, and consider issues such as longer life 
expectancy of women, and risk of loss of support due to death, abandonment, less stable earning patterns.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Social Protection Policy Specialist, Team Leader (9 person-months) 
1.  As team leader, the social protection specialist will be responsible for (i) coordinating 
team activities and ensuring efficient implementation of the tasks, coordinating with central and 
regional government counterparts and civil society representatives to ensure consultant team 
coordination with other support agencies; (ii) liaising with the Consultative Group for Indonesia 
(CGI) working group on health and education and the task forces on Poverty Reduction and 
Social  Security;  (iii)  taking  overall  responsibility  for  timely  preparation  and  submission  of 
required reports and ensuring quality and completeness of the reports, including a detailed work 
plan for the technical assistance (TA) and consultant team; (vi) incorporating appropriate gender 
focus;  (iv)  regularly  briefing  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  project officer; and (v) 
preparing a detailed project proposal, including a monitoring and evaluation framework for the 
project,  with  measurable  indicators  and  a  project  administration  memorandum  delineating 
project implementation procedures in detail to ensure that the proposed project is ready for ADB 
and Government appraisal. 
2.  As  a  specialist,  the  consultant  will  work  with  the  consultant  team  to  (i)  define,  in 
cooperation  with  the  consultant  team,  the  priority  target  groups  distinguishing  poor  and 
vulnerable populations, their exposure to risks, and needs for social protection arrangements; 
and develop criteria to reduce inefficiencies in reaching target groups; (ii) review and assess 
existing social protection schemes, both public and private, including nonformal schemes, and 
recommend strategies on how nonformal schemes can be linked to formal and nonformal 
systems;  (iii)  define  social  protection  in  Indonesia;  (iv)  produce  an  assessment  report  for 
discussion with the National Development Planning Board (BAPPENAS) and central technical 
team for the proposed sustainable social protection project, including recommendations for 
improving and establishing public-private social protection arrangements with a view to risk 
mitigation; (v) propose necessary capacity building of public and private institutions to address 
needs  of  the  target  group  through  adequate  social  protection  interventions;  (vi)  oversee 
planning for participatory planning workshops and seminars to assess needs; (vii) examine the 
accuracy and relevance of sources of data on poverty and suggest ways to strengthen and 
improve data collection; (viii) adapt lessons learned from developing integrated social protection 
schemes under decentralization; (ix) ensure full coordination between TA activities and activities 
under ongoing ADB TAs and loans; (x) prepare and facilitate an initial consultative workshop 
with  key  stakeholders,  including  central  and  local  government  officials,  parliamentary 
representatives,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  research  institutions,  and  funding 
agencies, to define the objectives, scope, and methodologies for the proposed project.  
2.  Social Insurance Specialist  (3 person-months) 
3.  Under the supervision of the team leader, the specialist will: (i) based on International 
Labour Organization (ILO) reports of restructuring social security and other relevant documents, 
examine the existing compensation system and consider a range of possible models for more 
effective and focused delivery of social insurance benefits to the poor, including administrative 
issues and management structures; (ii) assess existing social protection for the informal sector 
and identify and formulate in cooperation with the line ministries, central and local government 
project strategies, and recommend policy and project strategies to reduce vulnerability in the 
informal sector; (iii) assess current social services by the public and private sector for the

elderly, children, and disabled and recommend how to improve performance and targeting; (iii) 
explore options for microfinance for the poor initiatives, transfer programs for the poor, and 
recommend accordingly future safety net options; (iv) investigate all methods of targeting used 
in Government ministries in Indonesia and international agencies; (v) analyze current targeting 
methods and identify the appropriate approach for local governments taking into account gender 
considerations; (vi) recommend strategies to ensure equitable and adequate services for health 
and family planning for the poor; (vii) examine components of the existing social safety net 
(SSN) and recommend the potential for adjusting it to the local environment; (viii) liaise with the 
Consultative Group for Indonesia on social safety nets, the President’s Task Force for Poverty 
Reduction, and the President’s Task Force on Social Security; and (ix) help prepare and 
conduct workshops in cooperation with local facilitators. 
3.  Institutional Development Specialist (3 person-months) 
4.  The specialist will have a minimum of 3 years of project experience in Indonesia on 
preparing systems and programs for devolved social service programs and will (i) prepare an 
institutional strengthening and development plan;  (ii) prepare an implementation framework that 
defines roles of central and regional government in social protection; (iii) review the impact of 
the policy of decentralizing obligatory functions on social services and protection; (iv) determine 
the capacity of institutions to handle additional responsibilities for decentralized social services; 
(v) recommend institutional levels where social protection will be placed in the decentralized 
context; (vi) examine the capacity of the health, education, and welfare sector to better reach 
the poor and recommend services and interventions that can benefit the poor; (vii) recommend 
strategies  to  develop  awareness  campaigns  on  entitlements  for  the  poor  and  suggest 
information systems for eligible target groups; (viii) review medium- and long-term options for 
improved targeting of beneficiaries, including cash transfer systems for health, nutrition, and 
education services for the poor, building on the lessons learned from SSN schemes for health 
and education; (ix) recommend strategies to improve monitoring and evaluation systems for 
social protection schemes; (x) prepare an institutional strengthening plan for legal systems 
reform, especially inspection and enforcement of administrative and regulatory law regarding 
beneficiaries; (xi) assess training and human resources development needs for legal rights at 
central and local government levels; and (xii) assess the need for capacity building for NGOs 
and other private providers that can support implementation of a social protection system, 
4.   Labor Specialist (1 person-month) 
5.  The specialist will work  with the international team leader to (i) review all feasibility 
studies on employment, including benefits by ILO and other organizations; (ii) assess the 
adequacy of employment interventions as part of the SSN and recommend strategies that 
insure  sustainability  in  the  context  of  decentralization;  (iii)  identify  job  creation  schemes 
especially for the young unemployed and recommend strategies including possible public-
private partnership programs; (iv) assess the relevance and adequacy of vocational and skill 
training schemes and investigate prospects of links with the private sector; (v) assess the long-
term  viability  of  micro-credit  programs  for  self-employment;  (vi)  determine  the  impact  of 
employment law and minimum wage levels on employment; and (vii) recommend strategies for 
increasing participation in the workforce, especially for the poor and marginally poor in urban 
and rural areas.

5.   Social Protection Economist (3 person-months)  
6.  The economist will work in close cooperation with the team to (i) cost social protection 
measures proposed by the social protection, social insurance, and social assistance specialists; 
(ii) assess the cost-effectiveness of other potential social protection schemes, including income 
transfers and externalities of proposed schemes; (ii) model macroeconomic scenarios based on 
the number of expected beneficiaries distinguishing poor and vulnerable populations, expected 
levels of benefits, gross domestic product, and demographic scenarios, focusing on financial 
needs at national and regional levels, and identify probable disparities between provinces and 
needs for redistribution at the national level; (iii) assess possible financing sources and model 
scenarios of possible impacts on public budgets at national and provincial levels, taking into 
account  grant  assistance  and  contributions  from  beneficiaries;  (iv)  based  on  income  and 
expenditure scenarios, elaborate draft social budgets at national and regional levels according 
to ILO methodology; and (v) prepare a comprehensive analysis that supports the economic 
justification of the project, demonstrates the cost-effectiveness of project interventions, and 
gives a project cost estimate reflecting least-cost principles and validated unit costs in the 
decentralization context.   
B.  Domestic Consultants 
1.  Social Assistance Specialist, Deputy Team Leader (9 person-months) 
7.  Working under the supervision of the team leader and in close cooperation with the 
international social insurance specialist and counterparts in the line ministries, the specialist will 
(i)  support  the  preparation  of  participatory  workshops  to  define  objectives,  scope,  and 
methodologies to be used in the development of devolved social protection service delivery; (ii) 
review relevant legislation, policies, programs, and documents related to social welfare services 
to ascertain common elements, gaps, and constraints to be addressed in a devolved strategy; 
(iii)  explore options for micro-insurance initiatives, targeted traditional transfer, or other cash-
based systems; (iv) investigate all methods of targeting used in Government ministries in 
Indonesia  and  international  agencies;  (v)  analyze  these  and  other  targeting  methods  and 
identify the appropriate approach for Indonesia, taking into account gender considerations; (vi) 
examine nonformal social protection schemes, including poverty reduction and social assistance 
programs of civil society, and recommend strategies to complement these strategies with formal 
protection schemes such as social assistance.      
2.  Community Development Specialist (4 person-months) 
8.  The specialist will have had at least 3 years of related project experience and will (i) 
review the situation of the target groups, distinguish between poor and vulnerable populations at 
community level, and identify ways of expressing their needs through the poverty reduction 
analysis exercises; (ii) facilitate participatory workshops at various levels (province, district, and 
community)  to  assess  needs  and  help  prepare  district-level  proposals;  (iii)  prepare  a 
stakeholder analysis and report, and propose a participation strategy for implementation under 
the project; (iv) identify and formulate, in cooperation with the line ministries, government, and 
nongovernment institutions, a project strategy for community-level awareness to identify and 
support to the most vulnerable populations; and (v) develop a proposal for a communications 
strategy and dissemination of information about benefits and entitlement of social protection 
interventions at the local level.

3.  Gender and Poverty Specialist (3 person-months) 
9.  The specialist will work under the supervision of the team leader in cooperation with all 
members of the TA consultant team and will (i) conduct a gender analysis as part of the poverty 
and social analysis; (ii) help identify and address pertinent gender issues; (iii) assess the role of 
men in domestic violence and neglect and displacement of children, and recommend strategies 
for awareness building processes on social protection; (iv) recommend strategies and activities 
to prevent trafficking and sexual exploitation, and reintegrate children and young women into 
their families or communities; (v) propose capacity building for institutions dealing with children 
and women in especially difficult circumstances ; (vi) prepare a poverty and social analysis and 
strategy for the project following the guidelines of ADB’s  Handbook on Poverty and Social 
Analysis and ADB’s Guidelines for Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Bank Operations; (vii) 
indicate the poverty incidence and characteristics of poverty in the project areas (by income 
distribution or other measures); include numbers of poor women and children expected to be 
affected by the project and their net benefits; (viii) identify poor and vulnerable population 
groups in the targeted areas, and the likely impact of the project (including externalities); (ix) 
quantify the poverty impact of the project interventions either directly (e.g., numbers of women 
and children receiving services, and the availability of services, including referral systems); (x) 
work with the financial analyst to estimate unit benefits to unit costs received by poor and 
vulnerable households; (xi) estimate the poverty impact ratio, with sensitivity analysis regarding 
its reliability, as defined in the ADB’s Poverty and Social Analysis; (xii) examine the likelihood of 
benefit  leakages  to  the  non-poor  and  recommend  steps  to  avoid  leakages;  (xiii)  identify 
instruments for targeting and monitoring poverty impacts; and (xiv) work with the team leader 
and  management  specialist  to  identify  project  performance  indicators,  methodologies,  and 
human resources required to support the project management information system, baseline and 
later evaluation surveys, and monitoring of poverty impact in the project areas.   
4.  Management Specialist  (4 person-months) 
10.  The  consultant  will  work  with  the  international  team  leader  to  deliver  the  outputs 
specified in paragraph 1. The consultant will (i) design a management system that will include 
public  and  civil  partners,  with  clear  delineation  of  their  roles,  functions,  and  reporting 
responsibilities; (ii) create a governance framework for the project so that project planning, 
budgeting, resource monitoring, and auditing will create a sustainable system that can continue 
after  the  project;  (iii)  define  all  arrangements  for  project  implementation,  demonstrate  the 
relationship between relevant institutions and organizations, and indicate the chain of command 
and responsibilities for project implementation; and estimate the numbers and expertise of 
consulting staff, central and local government staff, staff from the private sector, and civil 
society; (iv) develop a monitoring and evaluation system for estimating benefits and results in 
accordance with ADB’s operational procedure for project performance, and with reference to 
ADB’s Handbook on Benefit Monitoring and Evaluation; (v) develop a  financial flow mechanism 
from  central  to  local  governments,  communities,  displaced  and  disadvantaged  persons  or 
families, and other institutions that take part in the project, in accordance with Government and 
ADB  rules;  and  (vi)  prepare  detailed,  measurable,  time-bound  monitoring  indicators  with 
reference to relevant baseline data.

11.  The analyst will prepare a comprehensive analysis that supports the financial justification 
of the project, demonstrates financial sustainability of project interventions, and gives a project 
cost estimate and validated unit costs in the decentralization context. The analyst will (i) assess

6.   Legal Specialist (3 person-months) 
12.  Working under the supervision of the team leader, the specialist will (i) review results of 
existing social protection projects and studies to consolidate the information with relevance to 
the planned project, identifying gaps and areas of special concern in a report; (ii) propose 
project strategies and possible activities for strengthening linkages and coordination with other 
agencies, including judiciary and law-enforcing agencies; (iii) identify key issues in the legal 
reform process that need to be addressed (e.g., denied access to legal assistance, etc.) in order 
to improve the access to the legal system of disadvantaged groups, including minors and 
households headed by females; and (iv) coordinate with local authorities and the private sector, 
including NGOs, to incorporate relevant legal issues and cross-cutting issues in proposed social 
protection activities. 
7.  Three Workshop Facilitators and Coordinators (2 person-months each) 
13.  The  workshop  facilitators  and  coordinators  will  have  special  responsibility  for 
coordinating the TA team’s collaboration with local advisory technical teams and additional 
stakeholders at decentralized levels. The consultants will (i) maintain coordination with the team 
leader and coteam leader in planning and facilitating workshops, (ii) facilitate collaboration with 
stakeholders and partners at decentralized level, and (iii) ensure that the results from the 
workshops are fully recorded and reported.
